images.title: Chris Downer / Oban: outlook from McCaig’s Tower
images.caption: Oban, outlook from McCaig's Tower

images.title: Chris Downer / Oban: McCaig’s Tower
images.caption: Oban, McCaig's Tower. This folly was built by John Stuart McCaig in 1895-1902. It may have been even bigger had his death not put a stop to things. Its wall runs in a complete circle and from its western end provides very good views over the bay.

images.title: Chris Downer / Oban: Catholic cathedral and Alexandra Hotel
images.caption: Catholic cathedral and Alexandra Hotel. Looking from the ferry, about to arrive from Mull, at the Catholic cathedral of St. Columba and its neighbours.

images.title: Chris Downer / Oban: morning view over bay
images.caption: Oban: morning view over bay. The isle of Kerrera beyond and Mull in the distance.

description: This coastal town sits in a lovely position on the Firth of Lorn in Argyll and Bute. There's a lovely harbour and bay with fine views to the surrounding islands of Kerrera and the Isle of Mull. This walk in the town takes you up to a fine viepwoint on McCaig's Tower before heading along the front to the cathedrals. The walk starts at the train station and heads north east through the town to climb to McCaig's Tower. There's excellent views over the town and the bay from this 19th century folly. The route then heads along the attractive promenade where you can enjoy a fine view across Oban Bay to Kerrera Island in the Scottish Inner Hebrides. For detailed information on the town's history, climate, culture, local attractions and transport links see the informative wikipedia page.
